questions.text: A 33-year-old male with attempted poisoning was brought to the casualty in a drowsy state. His pulse was 140/min, respiratory rate -30/min. His ABG showed metabolic acidosis. Urine analysis showed Calcium oxalate crystals. Identify the likely poison?
questions.explanation:
Ans. B. Ethylene glycol

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Ethylene glycol poisoning
  • ➤ Ethylene glycol poisoning
  • ➤ Ethylene glycol is the major constituent of antifreeze solutions. It is a clear, colorless, odorless, non-volatile liquid with a bitter-sweet taste.
  • ➤ Action: Ethylene glycol itself is not toxic, but the toxicity is due to metabolites glycolic and oxalic acids which inhibits oxidative phosphorylation.
  • ➤ Oxalic acid combines with calcium to form calcium oxalate crystals which accumulates in the proximal convoluted tubules causing renal failure. Metabolic acidosis occurs from glycolic acid. Ingestion of ethylene glycol produces CNS depression which may be accompanied by nausea, vomiting, and abdominal cramps . Metabolites of ethylene glycol produce severe metabolic acidosis and damage to the brain, heart, and kidneys
  • ➤ Oxalic acid combines with calcium to form calcium oxalate crystals which accumulates in the proximal convoluted tubules causing renal failure.
  • ➤ Metabolic acidosis occurs from glycolic acid.
  • ➤ Ingestion of ethylene glycol produces CNS depression which may be accompanied by nausea, vomiting, and abdominal cramps . Metabolites of ethylene glycol produce severe metabolic acidosis and damage to the brain, heart, and kidneys
  • ➤ CNS depression which may be accompanied by nausea, vomiting, and abdominal cramps
  • ➤ Treatment - Sodium bicarbonate, calcium gluconate, and 4-methyl pyrazole.

questions.text: A 3-month-old baby comes with complaints of deafness, cataract, and patent ductus arteriosus. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis? (NEET PG 2023)
questions.explanation:
Ans. D) Congenital rubella syndrome

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The triad of patent ductus arteriosus (PDA), cataract, and sensorineural hearing loss (SNHL) is diagnostic of congenital rubella syndrome (CRS).

questions.text: Which of the following neurotransmitters is released from SA node in response to increase in blood pressure?
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Acetylcholine

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ In summary, the correct neurotransmitter released from the SA node in response to an increase in blood pressure is acetylcholine, as it is part of the parasympathetic response to decrease heart rate and lower blood pressure.

questions.text: Identify the hormone from the picture?
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Growth Hormone

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Growth hormone levels exhibit significant variability, influenced by factors such as time of day, meals, exercise, and sleep, with the highest levels occurring during deep sleep. This pattern underlines the hormone's critical roles in growth, metabolism, and recovery processes.

questions.text: Which of the following children are considered at-risk babies? (NEET PG 2022) Baby with a birth weight of 2.5 kg Baby on artificial feeds Baby of working mother/single parent Baby with weight <85% of expected weight Birth order of 3 or more
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) 2, 3

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Infants on artificial feeding or with a working/single parent are at risk and require intensive care to prevent perinatal, neonatal, and infant mortality.

questions.text: Which of the following is not a cause of reversible dementia? (INICET MAY 2023)
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Lewy body dementia

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Lewy body dementia is not a reversible cause of dementia.

questions.text: A newborn female presents with continuous dribbling of urine. The image below shows the pathology from which the patient is suffering. The most likely diagnosis is: (AIIMS MAY 2018)
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Bladder exstrophy

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Bladder exstrophy presents as an exposed, inside-out bladder on the abdominal wall, often associated with continuous dribbling of urine, especially in female newborns with epispadias and bifid clitoris.

questions.text: PTH increases Calcium in blood. This is due to:

options.label: A
options.text: Rapid release of calcium by osteocytes

options.label: B
options.text: Rapid release of calcium by osteoclasts

options.label: C
options.text: Rapid release of calcium from bones and increased calcium reabsorption in kidneys

questions.correct_answer: C. Rapid release of calcium from bones and increased calcium reabsorption in kidneys
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Rapid release of calcium from bones and increased calcium reabsorption in kidneys:

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The educational objective here is to understand the role of parathyroid hormone (PTH) in regulating calcium levels in the blood and the mechanisms by which it accomplishes this task.
  • ➤ Role of PTH in Calcium Regulation: PTH is a hormone produced by the parathyroid glands, which are small glands located in the neck. Its primary function is to regulate calcium homeostasis in the body, ensuring that blood calcium levels remain within a narrow and critical range. Increase in Blood Calcium: PTH increases blood calcium levels by stimulating various physiological processes: Stimulation of Osteoclasts: PTH activates osteoclasts, specialized bone cells responsible for breaking down bone tissue. This results in the release of calcium from the bones into the bloodstream. Enhanced Calcium Reabsorption: PTH enhances the reabsorption of calcium by the kidneys. This means that less calcium is excreted in urine, conserving it for use in the body. Activation of Vitamin D: PTH indirectly stimulates the production of active vitamin D (calcitriol) in the kidneys. Calcitriol helps increase calcium absorption from the digestive tract, further contributing to higher blood calcium levels. Negative Feedback Loop: The regulation of PTH secretion is tightly controlled by a negative feedback loop. When blood calcium levels drop below the normal range, the parathyroid glands release PTH, which acts to raise calcium levels. Once calcium levels return to normal, PTH secretion decreases, preventing excess calcium in the blood.
  • ➤ Role of PTH in Calcium Regulation: PTH is a hormone produced by the parathyroid glands, which are small glands located in the neck. Its primary function is to regulate calcium homeostasis in the body, ensuring that blood calcium levels remain within a narrow and critical range.
  • ➤ Role of PTH in Calcium Regulation:
  • ➤ Increase in Blood Calcium: PTH increases blood calcium levels by stimulating various physiological processes: Stimulation of Osteoclasts: PTH activates osteoclasts, specialized bone cells responsible for breaking down bone tissue. This results in the release of calcium from the bones into the bloodstream. Enhanced Calcium Reabsorption: PTH enhances the reabsorption of calcium by the kidneys. This means that less calcium is excreted in urine, conserving it for use in the body. Activation of Vitamin D: PTH indirectly stimulates the production of active vitamin D (calcitriol) in the kidneys. Calcitriol helps increase calcium absorption from the digestive tract, further contributing to higher blood calcium levels.
  • ➤ Increase in Blood Calcium:
  • ➤ Stimulation of Osteoclasts: PTH activates osteoclasts, specialized bone cells responsible for breaking down bone tissue. This results in the release of calcium from the bones into the bloodstream. Enhanced Calcium Reabsorption: PTH enhances the reabsorption of calcium by the kidneys. This means that less calcium is excreted in urine, conserving it for use in the body. Activation of Vitamin D: PTH indirectly stimulates the production of active vitamin D (calcitriol) in the kidneys. Calcitriol helps increase calcium absorption from the digestive tract, further contributing to higher blood calcium levels.
  • ➤ Stimulation of Osteoclasts: PTH activates osteoclasts, specialized bone cells responsible for breaking down bone tissue. This results in the release of calcium from the bones into the bloodstream.
  • ➤ Stimulation of Osteoclasts:
  • ➤ Enhanced Calcium Reabsorption: PTH enhances the reabsorption of calcium by the kidneys. This means that less calcium is excreted in urine, conserving it for use in the body.
  • ➤ Enhanced Calcium Reabsorption:
  • ➤ Activation of Vitamin D: PTH indirectly stimulates the production of active vitamin D (calcitriol) in the kidneys. Calcitriol helps increase calcium absorption from the digestive tract, further contributing to higher blood calcium levels.
  • ➤ Activation of Vitamin D:
  • ➤ Negative Feedback Loop: The regulation of PTH secretion is tightly controlled by a negative feedback loop. When blood calcium levels drop below the normal range, the parathyroid glands release PTH, which acts to raise calcium levels. Once calcium levels return to normal, PTH secretion decreases, preventing excess calcium in the blood.
  • ➤ Negative Feedback Loop:

questions.text: A 56-year-old woman presents with 6 months of pain and stiffness in her hands, which is worse in the morning and lasts over an hour. On examination, her hands show swelling and joint deformities, as seen in the image. Laboratory tests show elevated inflammatory markers. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • Rheumatoid arthritis (RA) is a chronic autoimmune disease that primarily affects the small joints, including the hands, wrists, and feet. It typically presents with symmetrical joint pain and swelling , particularly involving the metacarpophalangeal (MCP) and proximal interphalangeal (PIP) joints. A hallmark feature of RA is morning stiffness lasting longer than 1 hour , which improves with activity, in contrast to other conditions like osteoarthritis where stiffness is shorter and worsens with use.
  • • Rheumatoid arthritis (RA)
  • • symmetrical joint pain and swelling
  • • morning stiffness lasting longer than 1 hour
  • • The joint deformities seen in RA, as illustrated in the image, occur due to chronic inflammation of the synovium (the lining of the joints), which leads to joint destruction over time. Common deformities include ulnar deviation , swan-neck deformities (hyperextension of the PIP joints with flexion of the DIP joints), and boutonnière deformities (flexion of the PIP joints with hyperextension of the DIP joints).
  • • ulnar deviation
  • • swan-neck deformities
  • • boutonnière deformities
  • • Laboratory findings in RA often show elevated inflammatory markers such as erythrocyte sedimentation rate (ESR) and C-reactive protein (CRP). Patients may also test positive for rheumatoid factor (RF) or anti-cyclic citrullinated peptide (anti-CCP) antibodies , which are more specific for RA.
  • • elevated inflammatory markers
  • • rheumatoid factor (RF)
  • • anti-cyclic citrullinated peptide (anti-CCP) antibodies
  • • Other Options:
  • • Other Options:
  • • Option A. Osteoarthritis : A degenerative joint disease that mainly affects large, weight-bearing joints like the knees and hips, with shorter morning stiffness and joint pain that worsens with activity.
  • • Option A. Osteoarthritis
  • • shorter morning stiffness
  • • Option B. Gout : An inflammatory arthritis that typically presents with acute monoarticular pain , most commonly in the first metatarsophalangeal (MTP) joint (big toe), not symmetrical polyarthritis.
  • • Option B. Gout
  • • acute monoarticular pain
  • • Option D. Psoriatic arthritis : An inflammatory condition associated with psoriasis that affects both skin and joints, but tends to involve asymmetrical joint involvement and dactylitis (sausage digits).
  • • Option D. Psoriatic arthritis
  • • psoriasis
  • • asymmetrical joint

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Rheumatoid arthritis (RA) is a chronic autoimmune condition that causes symmetrical polyarthritis , primarily affecting small joints. Key features include morning stiffness lasting over an hour , joint swelling, and progressive deformities. Early diagnosis and treatment with disease-modifying antirheumatic drugs (DMARDs) are crucial to prevent long-term joint damage and disability.
  • ➤ Rheumatoid arthritis (RA)
  • ➤ symmetrical polyarthritis
  • ➤ morning stiffness lasting over an hour

questions.text: In a patient with non-ST-elevation myocardial infarction (NSTEMI). All the following can be used for treatment except? (AIIMS MAY 2020)
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Streptokinase

Educational Objective:

questions.text: The most common manifestation of congenital toxoplasmosis is: (NEET PG 2019)
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Chorioretinitis

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Chorioretinitis is the most common manifestation of congenital toxoplasmosis, affecting up to 80% of infected infants and potentially leading to vision impairment or blindness.

questions.text: Handedness is seen at the age of? (INICET MAY 2022)
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) 3 years

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ At the age of 3 years, handedness is seen.

questions.text: A 30-year-old man is brought to the emergency department after being stabbed in the upper arm. Imaging reveals a significant tear in the brachial artery. The vascular surgeon plans to repair the damaged artery using a graft from another part of the patient's body. Which of the following is the most appropriate graft source for this procedure?
questions.explanation:
Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • The great saphenous vein is commonly used as a graft in vascular surgeries due to its accessibility, length, and suitability for arterial repair. In cases of brachial artery injury caused by trauma, such as a stab wound, repairing the artery with a vein graft allows for a tension-free anastomosis , which is essential for restoring proper blood flow. The great saphenous vein is typically harvested from the patient's leg (usually the uninjured leg) and is used to bypass or replace the damaged section of the brachial artery. This method is particularly effective when the artery has a significant tear or cannot be repaired by direct suturing alone.
  • • great saphenous vein
  • • brachial artery injury
  • • tension-free anastomosis
  • • great saphenous vein
  • • Other Options:
  • • Other Options:
  • • Option A) Radial artery: Although the radial artery can sometimes be used as a graft, it is less commonly harvested for such purposes due to its important role in maintaining blood supply to the hand.
  • • Option A) Radial artery:
  • • Option C) Femoral artery: The femoral artery is rarely used as a graft source because it is a major artery supplying the lower limb and its removal could lead to significant complications.
  • • Option C) Femoral artery:
  • • Option D) Subclavian vein: The subclavian vein is not typically used for grafting, as it plays a crucial role in venous return from the upper limb and would not be as suitable as the great saphenous vein for arterial repair.
  • • Option D) Subclavian vein:

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ For vascular repair, such as in cases of brachial artery injury , the great saphenous vein is often the preferred graft source due to its availability, ease of harvesting, and adaptability for arterial reconstruction. Using a vein graft allows for a tension-free repair and restoration of proper blood flow.
  • ➤ brachial artery injury
  • ➤ great saphenous vein

questions.text: True regarding the difference between adult and pediatric resuscitation? (AIIMS NOV 2018)

options.label: A
options.text: Ventricular dysrhythmias are common in children

options.label: B
options.text: The no flow phase precedes the period of cardiac arrest in children.

options.label: C
options.text: More ventilation to be given compared to chest compressions in children

options.label: D
options.text: Dysrhythmias are most often due to respiratory insufficiency in children

questions.correct_answer: D. Dysrhythmias are most often due to respiratory insufficiency in children
questions.explanation:
Ans. D) Dysrhythmias are most often due to respiratory insufficiency in children

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ In pediatric resuscitation, dysrhythmias are most commonly due to respiratory insufficiency or hypoxia, unlike in adults, where intrinsic cardiac causes are more prevalent.

questions.text: A child with thalassemia is undergoing multiple blood transfusions. What is the best method to detect iron overload? (INICET NOV 2022)
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Liver iron concentration

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The best method to detect iron overload in a patient receiving repeated blood transfusions is Liver iron concentration.

questions.text: A young child with congenital hydrocephalus was treated with a successful ventriculoperitoneal (VP) shunt. Four months post surgical repair, the child presented with fever, nuchal rigidity, and irritability. You suspect meningitis. What is the next best step? (NEET PG 2021)

options.label: B
options.text: Check shunt patency by nuclear study

options.label: C
options.text: Blood culture and take CSF sample from shunt tap

options.label: D
options.text: Blood culture and take CSF sample by lumbar puncture

questions.correct_answer: C. Blood culture and take CSF sample from shunt tap
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Blood culture and take CSF sample from shunt tap

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The best step for a child with a VP shunt showing signs of meningitis is to perform a blood culture and obtain a CSF sample from the shunt tap.

questions.text: A 45-year-old man developed generalized muscle spasm with arching of his back as shown in the image, a few days after sustaining a puncture wound to his leg. The toxin responsible for this type of abnormal posturing acts by which of the following mechanisms? (INICET MAY 2021)

options.label: A
options.text: Presynaptic inhibition of GABA and glycine release

options.label: D
options.text: Cleavage of SNARE proteins, preventing Ach release

questions.correct_answer: A. Presynaptic inhibition of GABA and glycine release
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Presynaptic inhibition of GABA and glycine release

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Tetanospasmin, the toxin responsible for tetanus, acts by inhibiting the presynaptic release of the inhibitory neurotransmitters GABA and glycine, leading to unopposed muscle contraction and the characteristic symptoms of tetanus, such as muscle spasms and opisthotonos.

questions.text: What type of tinea is likely affecting the 10-year-old child who presents with patchy hair loss as shown in the image below, along with the presence of black dots in the areas of hair loss?
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Endothrix

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The presence of patchy hair loss with black dots in the areas of hair loss in a child is indicative of an endothrix type of tinea capitis , where the fungal spores are located inside the hair shaft , causing it to break at the scalp level.
  • ➤ patchy hair loss
  • ➤ black dots
  • ➤ child
  • ➤ endothrix
  • ➤ tinea capitis
  • ➤ fungal spores
  • ➤ inside
  • ➤ hair shaft
  • ➤ break
  • ➤ scalp
  • ➤ Ref - Rook's Textbook of Dermatology - Volume II-9th Edition Chapter 32 Page no 32.8, 32.38-32.40
  • ➤ Ref - Rook's Textbook of Dermatology - Volume II-9th Edition Chapter 32 Page no 32.8, 32.38-32.40

questions.text: Which of the following is not a cause of secondary amenorrhea? (INICET NOV 2021)
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Kallman syndrome

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • Kallman syndrome is a condition of hypothalamic hypogonadism that presents as primary amenorrhea with anosmia. It does not cause secondary amenorrhea.
  • • Causes of secondary amenorrhea:
  • • Causes of secondary amenorrhea:
  • • Sheehan's syndrome: This is a condition where the pituitary gland is damaged due to severe blood loss during or after childbirth, leading to secondary amenorrhea. Asherman's syndrome: This condition involves the formation of scar tissue in the uterine cavity, often as a result of surgical procedures like dilation and curettage (D&C), leading to secondary amenorrhea. Turner mosaic: This refers to a form of Turner syndrome where some of the cells have the typical 45,X karyotype and others have a different karyotype (e.g., 46,XX). It can lead to secondary amenorrhea. Premature ovarian failure: This condition occurs when the ovaries stop functioning normally before age 40, causing secondary amenorrhea.
  • • Sheehan's syndrome: This is a condition where the pituitary gland is damaged due to severe blood loss during or after childbirth, leading to secondary amenorrhea.
  • • Sheehan's syndrome:
  • • Asherman's syndrome: This condition involves the formation of scar tissue in the uterine cavity, often as a result of surgical procedures like dilation and curettage (D&C), leading to secondary amenorrhea.
  • • Asherman's syndrome:
  • • Turner mosaic: This refers to a form of Turner syndrome where some of the cells have the typical 45,X karyotype and others have a different karyotype (e.g., 46,XX). It can lead to secondary amenorrhea.
  • • Turner mosaic:
  • • Premature ovarian failure: This condition occurs when the ovaries stop functioning normally before age 40, causing secondary amenorrhea.
  • • Premature ovarian failure:
  • • Other Options:
  • • Other Options:
  • • Option A. Turner's mosaic: A cause of secondary amenorrhea due to ovarian insufficiency.
  • • Option A. Turner's mosaic:
  • • Option C. Sheehan's syndrome: A cause of secondary amenorrhea due to pituitary damage.
  • • Option C. Sheehan's syndrome:
  • • Option D. Asherman's syndrome: A cause of secondary amenorrhea due to uterine scarring.
  • • Option D. Asherman's syndrome:

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Kallman syndrome is a cause of primary amenorrhea due to hypothalamic hypogonadism and anosmia. Secondary amenorrhea can be caused by conditions such as Sheehan's syndrome, Asherman's syndrome, Turner mosaic, and premature ovarian failure.
  • ➤ Ref: William’s textbook of gynecology 3 rd edition Pg375
  • ➤ Ref: William’s textbook of gynecology 3 rd edition Pg375

questions.text: Which of the following is false about influenza? (INICET NOV 2019)

options.label: A
options.text: Virus shedding is present before symptoms begins

questions.correct_answer: B. 5-12 years is a high-risk group
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) 5-12 years is a high-risk group

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Children under 5 years, pregnant women, the elderly, individuals with chronic medical conditions or immunosuppressive conditions, and health care workers are at greater risk of severe disease or complications from influenza. The 5-12 years age group is not specifically categorized as high-risk for severe disease from influenza.

questions.text: A 45-year-old woman reports with symptoms of lower urinary tract infection. She denies any pain or blood in the urine. Which of the following is not typically considered a lower urinary tract symptom (LUTS)?
questions.explanation:
Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • Urine leakage during intercourse (also known as coital incontinence) is not typically classified as a lower urinary tract symptom (LUTS). LUTS includes storage symptoms (e.g., frequency, urgency), voiding symptoms (e.g., weak stream, straining), and post-micturitional symptoms (e.g., incomplete bladder emptying). Although coital incontinence may occur in individuals with pelvic floor issues or urinary incontinence, it is not usually categorized as part of LUTS.
  • • Urine leakage during intercourse
  • • storage symptoms
  • • voiding symptoms
  • • post-micturitional symptoms
  • • Other Options:
  • • Other Options:
  • • Option A) Frequent urination : A storage symptom of LUTS, where the patient feels the need to urinate more frequently than normal.
  • • Option A) Frequent urination
  • • storage symptom
  • • Option B) Urgency : A storage symptom that involves a sudden, strong urge to urinate, which is difficult to delay.
  • • Option B) Urgency
  • • storage symptom
  • • Option C) Post-micturitional incomplete emptying : A post-micturitional symptom where the patient feels their bladder is not fully emptied after voiding.
  • • Option C) Post-micturitional incomplete emptying
  • • post-micturitional symptom

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Lower urinary tract symptoms (LUTS) include storage, voiding, and post-micturitional symptoms. Urine leakage during intercourse is not typically part of LUTS and may indicate pelvic floor or incontinence issues.
  • ➤ Lower urinary tract symptoms (LUTS)
  • ➤ Urine leakage during intercourse

questions.text: All of the following nerves are involved in the movement of the eyeball except:
questions.explanation:
Ans. A. A

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • The nerve marked as 'A' is the optic nerve (I CN), and is not involved in the movement of the eyeball.
  • • The optic nerve is primarily responsible for carrying visual information from the retina to the brain. It is not directly involved in controlling eye movements, but it is crucial for vision itself.
  • • The nerves marked in the image are:
  • • The nerves marked in the image are:
  • • A- Optic nerve (II CN) B- Oculomotor nerve (III CN) C- Abducens nerve (VI CN) D- Trochlear nerve (IV CN)
  • • A- Optic nerve (II CN)
  • • B- Oculomotor nerve (III CN)
  • • C- Abducens nerve (VI CN)
  • • D- Trochlear nerve (IV CN)
  • • Other Options:
  • • Other Options:
  • • Option B. Oculomotor nerve (III CN): The oculomotor nerve controls the majority of the eye's movements. It innervates several extraocular muscles responsible for moving the eye in various directions, including upward, downward, and medially. It also controls the pupil's constriction and the accommodation of the lens for focusing on near objects.
  • • Option B.
  • • Oculomotor nerve (III CN):
  • • Option C . Abducens nerve (VI CN): The abducens nerve controls the lateral rectus muscle, which is responsible for moving the eye outward or laterally. It allows for abduction of the eye, helping to look away from the nose.
  • • Option C
  • • Abducens nerve (VI CN):
  • • Option D. Trochlear nerve (IV CN): The trochlear nerve controls the superior oblique muscle, which is responsible for depressing the eye and intorsion (rotation inward). It helps in downward and inward eye movements.
  • • Option D.
  • • Trochlear nerve (IV CN):

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:

questions.text: The greenish-black color of the first stool in the newborn is due to: (NEET PG 2020)
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Biliverdin

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The greenish-black color of the first stool (meconium) in a newborn is due to biliverdin, a bile pigment.

questions.text: Identify the egg in the picture given below: (INICET NOV 2017)
questions.explanation:
Ans. D) Ancylostoma duodenale

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Hookworm eggs are oval, colorless, thin-shelled, and contain 4 to 8 blastomeres. These eggs are not bile-stained and have a clear space between the ovum and the eggshell.

questions.text: A patient presents with swelling below the left earlobe and is experiencing pain. What is the most likely cause of this pain? (NEET PG 2023)

options.label: B
options.text: Investing layer of deep cervical fascia

questions.explanation:
Ans. D. Greater auricular nerve

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Greater auricular nerve originates from the cervical plexus, specifically from the C2 and C3 spinal nerves. It ascends to the parotid gland and provides sensory innervation to the skin over the parotid gland, the earlobe, and the area behind the ear, so the greater auricular nerve is most directly responsible for transmitting pain sensations from these regions.
  • ➤ Greater auricular nerve

questions.text: Which of the following is not helpful for differentiating between necrosis and apoptosis? (INICET MAY 2024)

options.label: D
options.text: Internal organelle disintegration with lipid change

questions.explanation:
Ans.

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The key features to differentiate necrosis from apoptosis include the state of cell organelles (intact in apoptosis, disintegrated in necrosis), enzyme-mediated degradation (present in necrosis), and internal organelle disintegration with lipid changes (present in necrosis). Altered cell shape alone is not a useful parameter for differentiation.

questions.text: Under which of the following, Rhinosporidium seeberi is classified?
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Aquatic Protistan protozoa

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Rhinosporidium seeberi, responsible for rhinosporidiosis, is classified as an aquatic Protistan protozoa, not a fungus, highlighting the importance of accurate organism classification in understanding transmission and management of infections.

questions.text: A female presented with excessive daytime sleepiness and impaired concentration and memory for one year. On examination the BMI was 43 kg/m² and BP was 170/98 mmHg. ABG was done in awake state and the findings are given below. Which of the following is the likely diagnosis? PaO2: 70 mmHg PaCO2: 53 mmHg HCO3: 33 mmHg. (INICET MAY 2023)
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Obesity hypoventilation syndrome

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Obesity hypoventilation syndrome involves obesity, chronic hypercapnia, and hypoxemia, primarily in the awake state.

questions.text: The Thymus gland is specialized in identifying the molecules of the Major Histocompatibility Complex that are presented to it. It discerns whether these cells belong to the body's own or are of foreign origin. Which specific gene is accountable for this function? ( INICET MAY 2023)
questions.explanation:
Ans. D) AIRE

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The AIRE gene is crucial for promoting self-tolerance by ensuring that developing T cells in the thymus are exposed to self-antigens, thus preventing autoimmune diseases.

questions.text: A 6-year-old girl is admitted for evaluation for recurrent seizures. She has a large port-wine stain on her face as shown below. The MRI of the head shows a leptomeningeal angioma. What is the most common ocular manifestation of the underlying condition?
questions.explanation:
Ans. D) Glaucoma

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ In patients with Sturge-Weber syndrome, particularly those presenting with facial port-wine stains and neurological symptoms, glaucoma is a critical ocular manifestation to consider. Regular ophthalmic evaluations are essential due to the high incidence of glaucoma in these patients, focusing on managing elevated IOP to prevent vision loss.

questions.text: Efferent to which nucleus of thalamus from indicated structure in the image? (INICET NOV 2023)
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Anterior

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The fornix transmits signals from the hippocampus to the mammillary bodies, which then project to the anterior nucleus of the thalamus, playing a crucial role in memory processing within the Papez circuit.

questions.text: All of the following are the contents of the carotid sheath except?
questions.explanation:
Ans. A. Sympathetic chain

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • The carotid sheath's content is not the sympathetic chain. It is located in the neck, behind the carotid sheath and in front of the transverse processes of the cervical vertebrae.
  • • The carotid sheath is a layer of loose connective tissue formed by adjacent portions of the investing layer of deep cervical fascia, the pretracheal fascia, and the prevertebral fascia.
  • • Contents of carotid sheath:
  • • Contents of carotid sheath:
  • • Common and internal carotid arteries Internal jugular vein Vagus nerve Ansa cervicalis
  • • Common and internal carotid arteries
  • • Internal jugular vein
  • • Vagus nerve
  • • Ansa cervicalis
  • • Note: The glossopharyngeal, accessory, and hypoglossal nerves are located in the carotid sheath's upper portion.
  • • Note:
  • • Other Options:
  • • Other Options:
  • • Option B . Carotid artery : The common carotid artery and its internal branch (the internal carotid artery) are primary contents of the carotid sheath. In the neck, the common carotid bifurcates into the internal and external carotid arteries. Only the internal carotid artery continues to ascend within the carotid sheath.
  • • Option B
  • • Carotid artery
  • • Option C . Internal jugular vein : The internal jugular vein is a major vein in the neck that drains the brain, face, and much of the neck. It runs in close proximity to the internal and common carotid arteries and is another primary content of the carotid sheath.
  • • Option C
  • • Internal jugular vein
  • • Option D . 9th cranial nerve : The 9th cranial nerve, also known as the glossopharyngeal nerve, is involved in the sensory and motor functions of the tongue and pharynx. It descends from the skull base through the jugular foramen and is present in the carotid sheath. It's more lateral and posteriorly positioned in the sheath relative to the carotid artery and the internal jugular vein.
  • • Option D
  • • 9th cranial nerve

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The sympathetic chain (sympathetic trunk) is a bilateral series of ganglia that run vertically alongside the vertebral column. It is involved in the autonomic sympathetic innervation of the body. Importantly, the sympathetic chain itself is not contained within the carotid sheath. However, sympathetic fibers that come from the chain (e.g., the carotid plexus) do accompany structures within the sheath, especially the internal and common carotid arteries.

questions.text: A 12-year-old boy presents to the emergency department with acute abdominal pain and is diagnosed with intussusception. During surgical intervention, multiple polyps are discovered throughout his gastrointestinal tract. A resected segment of the bowel is sent for histopathological analysis, and the findings are shown in the image below. Considering the clinical scenario and histopathological features, what is the most likely type of polyp?
questions.explanation:
Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • A hamartomatous polyp is characterized by disorganized but normal tissue elements from the GI tract, which are often found in conditions like Peutz-Jeghers syndrome or juvenile polyposis syndrome . These polyps are benign and do not have a significant risk of malignant transformation but may cause complications like intussusception due to their size or location.
  • • hamartomatous polyp
  • • Peutz-Jeghers syndrome
  • • juvenile polyposis syndrome
  • • Other Options:
  • • Other Options:
  • • Option A) Adenomatous polyp: Adenomatous polyps are premalignant and have a risk of transforming into colorectal cancer, often showing dysplasia, which is not seen in this case.
  • • Option A) Adenomatous polyp:
  • • Option C) Hyperplastic polyp: Hyperplastic polyps are benign and typically occur in the distal colon without causing significant symptoms like abdominal pain or bleeding.
  • • Option C) Hyperplastic polyp:
  • • Option D) Inflammatory polyp: Inflammatory polyps are usually associated with inflammatory bowel diseases and present in patients with chronic GI inflammation, which is not seen in this case.
  • • Option D) Inflammatory polyp:

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Hamartomatous polyps are benign growths made up of disorganized but normal tissue. They are commonly seen in children and adolescents, particularly in syndromes like Peutz-Jeghers and juvenile polyposis , and may lead to complications such as intussusception.
  • ➤ Hamartomatous polyps
  • ➤ Peutz-Jeghers
  • ➤ juvenile polyposis

questions.text: The term "paradoxical carrier" is defined as: (NEET PG 2019)

options.label: A
options.text: A person who sheds pathogens during incubation period

options.label: B
options.text: A carrier who acquired pathogen from another carrier

options.label: C
options.text: A person who acquired pathogen from patient

options.label: D
options.text: A patient who became a carrier

questions.correct_answer: B. A carrier who acquired pathogen from another carrier
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) A carrier who acquired pathogen from another carrier

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ A paradoxical carrier is a carrier who has acquired a pathogen from another carrier, but who does not show any signs or symptoms of the disease. Incubatory carriers are those who shed the infectious agents during the incubation period of the disease. Convalescent carriers are those who continue to shed the disease agent during the period of convalescence. Healthy carriers are those who had a subclinical infection and developed a carrier state without suffering from overt disease.
  • ➤ A paradoxical carrier is a carrier who has acquired a pathogen from another carrier, but who does not show any signs or symptoms of the disease.
  • ➤ paradoxical carrier
  • ➤ Incubatory carriers are those who shed the infectious agents during the incubation period of the disease.
  • ➤ Incubatory carriers
  • ➤ Convalescent carriers are those who continue to shed the disease agent during the period of convalescence.
  • ➤ Convalescent carriers
  • ➤ Healthy carriers are those who had a subclinical infection and developed a carrier state without suffering from overt disease.
  • ➤ Healthy carriers

questions.explanation:

questions.text: A 45-year-old male worker presents to the emergency room with abdominal pain, irritability, fatigue, and memory problems. He works in a battery manufacturing factory for the last 20 years. On further investigations, he is diagnosed with lead poisoning. Which of the following is the most frequent mode of inorganic lead absorption contributing to his condition in such industrial environments? (INICET MAY 2021)

options.label: C
options.text: Ingestion of contaminated food and water

questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Inhaled lead dust

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Lead Poisoning is known as ‘Plumbism’, Saturnism or Painter’s Colic
  • ➤ Lead Poisoning is known as ‘Plumbism’, Saturnism or Painter’s Colic
  • ➤ Greatest source of lead in Lead Poisoning (Plumbism, Saturnism or Painter’s Colic) is Gasoline/petrol /vehicular exhaust/automobile exhaust Mode of absorption: Lead can be absorbed by inhalation (most common mode), ingestion or through skin
  • ➤ Greatest source of lead in Lead Poisoning (Plumbism, Saturnism or Painter’s Colic) is Gasoline/petrol /vehicular exhaust/automobile exhaust
  • ➤ Gasoline/petrol
  • ➤ Mode of absorption: Lead can be absorbed by inhalation (most common mode), ingestion or through skin
  • ➤ inhalation (most common mode),
  • ➤ Additional Information
  • ➤ Additional Information
  • ➤ Clinical picture of lead poisoning:
  • ➤ Clinical picture of lead poisoning:
  • ➤ Facial pallor: Earliest and most consistent sign Anemia: Microcytic hypochromic Punctate basophilia or basophilic stippling of RBCs Burtonian Line: Lead sulphide line on gums (upper jaw) Lead colic: Constipation (but sometimes diarrhea) Lead Palsy (Peripheral neuropathy): Wrist drop or Foot drop Lead encephalopathy CNS effects: mostly due to organic lead compounds
  • ➤ Facial pallor: Earliest and most consistent sign
  • ➤ Anemia: Microcytic hypochromic
  • ➤ Punctate basophilia or basophilic stippling of RBCs
  • ➤ Burtonian Line: Lead sulphide line on gums (upper jaw)
  • ➤ Burtonian Line: Lead sulphide line on gums (upper jaw)
  • ➤ Lead colic: Constipation (but sometimes diarrhea)
  • ➤ Lead Palsy (Peripheral neuropathy): Wrist drop or Foot drop
  • ➤ Lead encephalopathy
  • ➤ CNS effects: mostly due to organic lead compounds
  • ➤ Diagnosis of lead poisoning:
  • ➤ Diagnosis of lead poisoning:
  • ➤ A useful screening test is Coproporphyrin in Urine (CPU).
  • ➤ Treatment: EDTA

questions.text: All of the following characteristics are found in the pleural effusion fluid of a rheumatoid arthritis patient except: (AIIMS MAY 2019)

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:

questions.text: A patient came to hospital who has not eaten anything for 2 days. Which of the following tests will be positive?
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Only 3

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • Prolonged fasting leads to ketonuria which can be detected by Rothera’s test i.e., test 3
  • • Prolonged fasting leads to ketonuria which can be detected by Rothera’s test i.e., test 3
  • • Rothera's test: Saturate 5 mL of urine with solid ammonium sulphate. Add a few drops of freshly prepared sodium nitroprusside followed by 2 mL of liquor ammonia along the sides of the test tube. Development of a purple ring indicates the presence of ketone bodies in urine . Strip tests based on the same principle are also available.
  • • Rothera's test:
  • • purple ring indicates the presence of ketone bodies in urine
  • • Other tests
  • • Other tests
  • • Test 1: Benedict’s test: To 5 mL Benedict’s reagent, add 0.5 mL urine. Boil for 2 minutes. Blue, green, yellow, orange or red precipitate indicate reducing sugars. Black colour (muddy brown) is seen if homogentisic acid is present. Disaccharides may be identified by alkali destruction test. As there is low glucose in blood and will not be excreted in urine. So It will be negative.
  • • Test 1: Benedict’s test:
  • • Blue, green, yellow, orange or red precipitate indicate reducing sugars.
  • • The urine of a patient with diabetic keto acidosis will give positive Benedict's test as well as Rothera's test. But in starvation ketosis, Benedict's test is negative, but Rothera's test will be positive.
  • • But in starvation ketosis, Benedict's test is negative, but Rothera's test will be positive.
  • • Test 2: S hows the heat coagulation test . The heat coagulation test is used to detect the presence of proteins in urine. Since proteins are generally conserved during fasting to protect muscle mass, this test will be negative, rather proteins will be conserved to protect muscles.
  • • Test 2:
  • • S
  • • hows the heat coagulation test

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective
  • ➤ Prolonged fasting leads to ketosis, which can be detected by Rothera’s test (test 3), resulting in a positive result for ketone bodies in the urine.

questions.text: Assertion: In a patient admitted in hospital for community acquired pneumonia, combination therapy of beta lactams and azithromycin is given. Reason: The combination covers gram positive organisms as well as anaerobes.

options.label: A

options.label: B

options.label: D

questions.text: A young girl presents with the complaints of continuous dribbling of urine. However, she also voids normally. Her parents tell you that she had never been totally dry since her birth. What is the most likely diagnosis? (INICET NOV 2020)
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Ectopic ureter

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ An ectopic ureter should be suspected in a young female with continuous dribbling of urine since birth, despite normal voiding, due to the abnormal insertion of the ureter outside the bladder.

questions.text: Nitric oxide is synthesized from: (NEET PG 2020)

  • ➤ NO (nitric oxide) is
  • ➤ synthesized from arginine by enzyme NOS
  • ➤ NO is also called as Endothelium Derived Relaxing Factor (EDRF). It causes vasodilatation and acts through the formation of secondary messenger cGMP.
  • ➤ NOS (multienzyme complex)
  • ➤ NOS (multienzyme complex)
  • ➤ There are three isoforms of NOS iNOS- inducible nNOS - neuronal eNOS- endothelial
  • ➤ There are three isoforms of NOS iNOS- inducible nNOS - neuronal eNOS- endothelial
  • ➤ iNOS- inducible nNOS - neuronal eNOS- endothelial
  • ➤ iNOS- inducible
  • ➤ nNOS - neuronal
  • ➤ eNOS- endothelial

questions.text: Which of the following opioids is an antagonist at ‘µ’ and a complete agonist at ‘k’ receptors? (AIIMS MAY 2017)
questions.explanation:
Ans. A. Pentazocine

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Pentazocine is an opioid that acts as an antagonist at mu (μ) receptors and a full agonist at kappa (κ) receptors. This unique profile allows it to serve as an analgesic with a potentially lower risk of certain side effects, although it is contraindicated in myocardial infarction.

questions.text: An 11-year-old child who weighs 26 kg with a history of streptococcal pharyngitis presents to you with fever and arthralgia. There is no past history of rheumatic heart disease or features of carditis or valvular disease. How often is benzathine penicillin recommended for prophylaxis of rheumatic heart disease? (Neet pg 2022)

options.label: A

options.label: B

options.label: C
options.text: 1200000 IU Once in 3 weeks for 10 years

options.label: D
options.text: 1200000 IU Once in 3 weeks for life

questions.explanation:
Ans.

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ For an 11-year-old child weighing 26 kg with a history of streptococcal pharyngitis and no carditis or valvulitis, benzathine penicillin G prophylaxis should be administered at a dose of 600,000 IU every 3 weeks for a duration of 10 years (until the child turns 21 years old).

questions.text: A 55-year-old lady presents with third degree uterine prolapse. Which of the following is the best management for her?( NEET PG 2019 )

options.label: C
options.text: Vaginal hysterectomy with pelvic floor repair

questions.correct_answer: C. Vaginal hysterectomy with pelvic floor repair
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Vaginal hysterectomy with pelvic floor repair

Explanation:

  • • Explanation
  • • In the given case scenario, vaginal hysterectomy with pelvic floor repair is the ideal management. This is also called as Ward Mayo repair This is recommended to patients who satisfy the following criteria: >40 years of age Have completed their families Do not wish to preserve menstrual and child-bearing function
  • • In the given case scenario, vaginal hysterectomy with pelvic floor repair is the ideal management.
  • • This is also called as Ward Mayo repair
  • • This is recommended to patients who satisfy the following criteria: >40 years of age Have completed their families Do not wish to preserve menstrual and child-bearing function
  • • >40 years of age Have completed their families Do not wish to preserve menstrual and child-bearing function
  • • >40 years of age
  • • Have completed their families
  • • Do not wish to preserve menstrual and child-bearing function
  • • Other Options:
  • • Other Options:
  • • Option A. Fothergill repair : This is also known as Manchester repair and involves conserving the uterus. In this procedure, cervical amputation with plication of the cardinal ligaments is done. It is done in young women who have completed their families with utero-vaginal prolapse.
  • • Option A. Fothergill repair
  • • Option B. Sling operation : This is preferred in women who are young, nulliparous (yet to have children/ complete their families) with prolapse
  • • Option B. Sling operation
  • • Option D. Shirodkar procedure : This is a modification of Manchester/ Fothergill surgery and does not include cervical amputation
  • • Option D. Shirodkar procedure

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Vaginal hysterectomy with pelvic floor repair (Ward Mayo repair) is the preferred management for older women (>40 years) with third degree uterine prolapse who have completed their families and do not wish to preserve menstrual and child-bearing function.
  • ➤ Vaginal hysterectomy with pelvic floor repair (Ward Mayo repair) is the preferred management for older women (>40 years) with third degree uterine prolapse who have completed their families and do not wish to preserve menstrual and child-bearing function.
  • ➤ Ref: Page 221, DC Dutta’s Textbook of Gynecology 6 th edition
  • ➤ Ref: Page 221, DC Dutta’s Textbook of Gynecology 6 th edition

questions.text: A 45-year-old male patient was diagnosed with iron deficiency anemia. Which of the following is true about intracellular regulation of iron in the above condition? (AIIMS NOV 2021)

questions.text: Premature aging in Werner syndrome is due to: (NEET PG 2020)

options.label: C
options.text: Increase in length of telomere due to decrease in telomerase activity

questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Defect in DNA helicase

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Premature aging in Werner syndrome is primarily due to a defect in DNA helicase, leading to rapid accumulation of chromosomal damage and the manifestation of aging-related symptoms at an accelerated rate.

questions.text: A healthcare worker is cleaning up after a procedure involving a blood draw. She has several items to dispose of, as mentioned below. According to proper biomedical waste management guidelines, which of the following should be disposed of in the red bin?
questions.explanation:
Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • The red bin is designated for contaminated recyclable waste , such as used gloves, tubing, and plastic items that have been exposed to bodily fluids. The used gloves in this case should be disposed of in the red bin, as they have been in contact with a patient and are considered contaminated medical waste.
  • • red bin
  • • contaminated recyclable waste
  • • Other Options:
  • • Other Options:
  • • Option A) Used syringe with needle : This belongs in a sharps bin , designed for the safe disposal of needles, scalpels, and other sharp items to prevent injury and infection.
  • • Option A) Used syringe with needle
  • • sharps bin
  • • Option B) Blood-soiled gauze : Should be disposed of in the yellow bin , which is used for biomedical waste , such as items contaminated with blood or bodily fluids. These require disinfection or incineration.
  • • Option B) Blood-soiled gauze
  • • yellow bin
  • • biomedical waste
  • • Option D) Paper wrapper from gloves : Should be placed in the black bin , which is for non-infectious general waste, like paper wrappers or food waste.
  • • Option D) Paper wrapper from gloves
  • • black bin

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:

questions.text: Which of the following drugs used in the management of type 2 diabetes is associated with an increased risk of urinary tract infections? (INICET MAY 2024)
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Dapagliflozin

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Dapagliflozin, an SGLT2 inhibitor, is associated with an increased risk of urinary tract infections due to its mechanism of increasing glucose excretion in the urine. This highlights the importance of monitoring for UTIs in patients prescribed this medication.

questions.text: Pregnant women with which of the following is called systemic hypertension? (INICET MAY 2017)

options.label: A
options.text: Hypertension diagnosed at 10 weeks of gestation

questions.correct_answer: A. Hypertension diagnosed at 10 weeks of gestation
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Hypertension diagnosed at 10 weeks of gestation

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • Systemic hypertension in pregnancy is classified as chronic hypertension if it is diagnosed in the first trimester or if hypertension persists beyond 12 weeks postpartum. Hypertension present before pregnancy or diagnosed before the 20th week of gestation also qualifies as chronic hypertension. This is distinct from gestational hypertension, which develops after 20 weeks of gestation in a previously normotensive woman.
  • • Chronic Hypertension: Defined as blood pressure of ≥ 140/90 mm Hg that was present before pregnancy or diagnosed before the 20th week of gestation.
  • • Chronic Hypertension: Defined as blood pressure of ≥ 140/90 mm Hg that was present before pregnancy or diagnosed before the 20th week of gestation.
  • • Chronic Hypertension:
  • • Other Options:
  • • Other Options:
  • • Option B. Diabetic retinopathy: This condition is a complication of diabetes affecting the eyes, not a direct indicator of systemic hypertension.
  • • Option B. Diabetic retinopathy:
  • • Option C. Diabetic nephropathy: This is a complication of diabetes that affects the kidneys and can be associated with hypertension, but it is not specific to the definition of systemic hypertension in pregnancy.
  • • Option C. Diabetic nephropathy:
  • • Option D. Episode of seizure: Seizures in the context of pregnancy are associated with eclampsia, a severe form of preeclampsia, but do not directly define systemic hypertension.
  • • Option D. Episode of seizure:

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Systemic hypertension in pregnancy is diagnosed if high blood pressure is present before pregnancy, is diagnosed before 20 weeks of gestation, or persists beyond 12 weeks postpartum.
  • ➤ Ref: Page no 1778, Williams Obstetrics 26 th edition
  • ➤ Ref: Page no 1778, Williams Obstetrics 26 th edition

questions.text: A 39 year G2P1 presents at 18 weeks 5 days for her routine targeted fetal anomaly ultrasound. The fetal anatomy appears normal, but the cervical length is 15mm. Despite being counselled that there is no clear proven benefit for the same; the patient insisted on a cervical cerclage. Which of the following is a complete contra-indication to cerclage? (NEET PG 2022)
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Ruptured membranes

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • Ruptured Membranes: Ruptured membranes are a complete contraindication to cerclage. When the membranes are ruptured, there is an increased risk of infection and complications, making the procedure unsafe. Cerclage involves stitching the cervix closed to prevent premature birth, which is not advisable when the protective amniotic sac is compromised.
  • • Ruptured Membranes: Ruptured membranes are a complete contraindication to cerclage. When the membranes are ruptured, there is an increased risk of infection and complications, making the procedure unsafe. Cerclage involves stitching the cervix closed to prevent premature birth, which is not advisable when the protective amniotic sac is compromised.
  • • Ruptured Membranes:
  • • Ruptured membranes are a complete contraindication to cerclage. When the membranes are ruptured, there is an increased risk of infection and complications, making the procedure unsafe. Cerclage involves stitching the cervix closed to prevent premature birth, which is not advisable when the protective amniotic sac is compromised.
  • • Ruptured membranes are a complete contraindication to cerclage. When the membranes are ruptured, there is an increased risk of infection and complications, making the procedure unsafe.
  • • Cerclage involves stitching the cervix closed to prevent premature birth, which is not advisable when the protective amniotic sac is compromised.
  • • Other Options:
  • • Other Options:
  • • Option A. Positive fetal fibronectin test: A positive fetal fibronectin test indicates an increased risk of preterm labor but is not an absolute contraindication to cerclage. This test measures the presence of fetal fibronectin, a protein that acts as a "glue" during pregnancy, keeping the amniotic sac attached to the lining of the uterus.
  • • Option A. Positive fetal fibronectin test:
  • • Option B. Membranes bulging into the vagina: While bulging membranes present a high-risk situation, they are not an absolute contraindication to cerclage. In some cases, cerclage can still be performed with careful management.
  • • Option B. Membranes bulging into the vagina:
  • • Option D. Advanced maternal age: Advanced maternal age is not a contraindication to cerclage. While it may increase the overall risk profile of the pregnancy, it does not specifically contraindicate the procedure.
  • • Option D. Advanced maternal age:

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Ruptured membranes are a complete contraindication to cervical cerclage due to the increased risk of infection and complications.
  • ➤ Ref: Page 543, Williams Obstetrics 26 th edition
  • ➤ Ref: Page 543, Williams Obstetrics 26 th edition

questions.text: Identify the type of knot seen in the image given below:
questions.explanation:
Ans. B. Reef knot

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective: The reef knot has
  • ➤ Two Throws in “Opposite Directions”
  • ➤ Two Throws in “Opposite Directions”

questions.text: Drug resistance is most commonly seen with which of the following infections?
questions.explanation:
Ans. D) Gonorrhea

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ In summary, gonorrhea is the infection most commonly associated with drug resistance, making it a critical concern in the treatment of STIs.

questions.text: What is the investigation of choice for neurosyphilis? (NEET PG 2019)

options.label: B
options.text: FTA-ABS- Fluorescent Treponemal Antibody Absorption test

questions.correct_answer: A. Venereal disease research laboratory (VDRL) test
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Venereal disease research laboratory (VDRL) test

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The CSF-VDRL test, despite its low sensitivity, remains the gold standard for the diagnosis of neurosyphilis due to its high specificity when positive. It is crucial in the diagnostic process for patients with suspected syphilis infection of the central nervous system, helping guide appropriate treatment and management.
